history.content: Took 3 UD in one semester, 170, 189, and 168  together. Got the worst grades I've gotten all my Berkeley career so far, but it overall the semester was still pretty good. I think you can do this for a semester and really ask yourself if you want to repeat it again.

children.subject:
I think this would be different for everyone.  You should have an idea of how strong of a student you are.  

If you struggled with similar schedules in the past, or needed to put in significant time in classes to be successful, then it may be more intensive for you.  

On the other hand, if you found your previous EECS courses easier, and could get A's with relative ease, then I think 3 techs would be completely manageable.

These numbers are no where near exact, but I imagine a top 10% EECS student could do well on 4 techs.  Maybe 30% could do well with 3, and a lighter H/ss.

Also depends on what your expectations are for grades.  If you are aiming for A's, this will make it a lot harder.  If you are looking for B's, I think it is more feasable, especially with the new higher grading guidelines.

It's doable, and you can actually do well (and have a good time as well), it just requires smart planning.  Not all upper div's are equal in workload- be sure to mix the difficult/heavy workload classes with easier ones and you will be fine.  No matter what you do (even if you want to push yourself) however, do not take three project courses in the same semester.

history.content:
Also note that upper divisions have different workloads depending on the class. 

Workload

CS 150/EE 141/EECS151 (Digital Systems), CS 152 (Computer Architecture), CS 162 (Operating Systems), CS 164(Programming Languages and Compilers), CS 169 (Software Engineering), CS 170 (CS Theory), CS 184 (Computer Graphics), and CS 189 (Machine Learning) are known to have heavy workloads. It is not recommended to take these courses in combination.
I'm currently reviewing my academic planning. How realistic is it to take three UD EECS courses as my main load for two semesters, totaling 6 eecs courses in one year? Any insight is appreciated.
history.subject: Three Upper Division EECS Courses Per Semester
